answers.answer: Also all the sensations or paresthesias have been all over my body.
Also random muscle twitches in random places. That's it lol

Hi and welcome!  I'm afraid I don't know enough to be able to give you much advice.  I am searching for answers, too!  Just wanted you to know that you aren't alone.  I know it is hard, but try not to overdose on Dr. Google.  Hey, we've all done it.  It is good to educate yourself, yet keep an open mind.You are doing the right things by getting checked out and going to see a neurologist.  If you haven't already, you may want to type a brief list of symptoms and timelines.  Also, I wouldn't recommend telling the neuro that you suspect any particular condition.  Be honest, tell him your symptoms, and if he is a good neuro he should give you an exam, then based on the information he gathers, will possibly order more tests.Hang around, others with more knowledge will hopefully chime in soon.Best of luck,Minnie  :)

Hi and welcome.  I am glad to hear you are seeing a neurologist this week.  The thing that jumps out at me is your comment that you are in the prediabetes stage.  Elevated blood sugar can do all sorts of this to the nervous system. A good cross reference list of symptoms and diseases that mimi MS can be found athttp://www.umm.edu/altmed/articles/multiple-sclerosis-000474.htmDiabetes can cause fatigue, numbness and  vision problems  among other things and it would be good if you can get this under control, whether it is causing your other problems of not.Good luck at the neuro and be sure to let us know how the appointment unfolds.
Thanks for the advice! Best of luck to you too. Hopefully it's not what we're thinking.

Thats what I've been thinking it might be related to diabetes as well because I have a cataract. It's completely odd that I have a cataract at this age. I just hope it's nothing too serious. Do you know if parethesia is common in MS?
Cataracts are one of the known vision problems caused by diabetes.  My diabetic father developed one.

question: I am extremely concerned an frightened that I have MS. I am a 20 year old African American male. Here are a list of my symptoms:Constant tingling that started in right foot and then began in left footFeels like the tingling moved up my legs but feels like a more shaky feelingHands feel like they fall asleep; however only get this sensation when waking up or resting on my elbowsBurning and itching sensations that come and go and really don't happen that oftenPressure on my ankles and feet that doesn't happen too oftenVision seems like it got worse; went to eye doctor and found out I have a cataract in one eyeSlight blurry vision when waking up; happens rarelyWeird pain sensations in random places rarelyWeird feeling in kneesThrobbing or heartbeat feeling in feet and handsThrobbing in back of headI know that is a lot but that is what I have been experiencing for the last two months. Every sensation is intermittent except the tingling in feet and legs. That tingling is constant everyday. I got my b12 level checked and it was 363. I also had my blood sugar level checked and I was in the prediabtes range. Does this sound like MS. I have literally been on google everyday since the slight tingling in my foot began and I have had anxiety about these sensations ever since. Does this sound like MS? I have a neurologist appointment this Thursday. Any thoughts? You can be extremely honest, I can handle it. :-)
title: Does MS sound likely?
